page.title: 07Rousham House and Village
page.content: Rousham House was built about 1600 but extended in 1737 by William Kent who also laid out the gardens. They are the only surviving example of a Kent garden design, and the owner, Mr Cottrell-Dormer is doing his best to make sure that they are preserved for the future. The village, outside the gates, was built about 1770 when the park was enclosed. It has mains electricity but not mains drainage or natural gas. Now very few of the inhabitants work on the estate. The school has closed down because there are only six children in the village, and they have to go to Steeple Aston (five miles away) until they are eleven, and then to Bloxham. There are only services in the church (built in 1500) on the first Sunday in the month, as there is no resident clergyman.
